properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:

To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert Continued For The Red River Between Emerson And The Red River Floodway Inlet Control Structure
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Red River between Emerson and the Red River Floodway Inlet Control Structure due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2020-04-03T12:30:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2020-04-02T12:50:47-05:00, 7BFDE115-1C58-D889-1C97-3B493EB3F335
Area: The Red River from Emerson to the Red River Floodway Inlet Control Structure
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain possible Friday. Rain is forecast to transition to a period of freezing rain Friday afternoon and then to snow Friday evening. The freezing rain could be mixed with ice pellets before the change to snow. Ice accretion is most likely on elevated surfaces however untreated highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may also become icy and slippery. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wintry mix of rain, freezing rain and snow continuing into Friday. Rain will change to freezing rain then snow tonight. Total rainfall amounts of 15 to 25 mm are possible by midnight mainly for areas east of a line from Kenora to Rainy River. Snowfall amounts of 5 cm are likely along the Ontario-Manitoba border by Friday morning, with an additional 5 to 10 cm expected on Friday. A freezing rain warning is also in effect for tonight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain expected Friday morning. Rain is expected to change to freezing rain Friday morning. The freezing rain will likely last for several hours before changing to snow near midday Friday. Up to 5 mm of ice accretion or build up is possible. Ice accretion is most likely on elevated surfaces however untreated highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may also become icy and slippery. ### Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain continuing into Friday with freezing rain possible. A slow moving cold front will continue to bring rain to areas from Ear Falls to Quetico Provincial Park today. Total rainfall amounts in the 15 to 25 mm range are likely by midday Friday when the rain should transition to snow with the passage of the cold front. Freezing rain is also likely as the rain transitions to snow on Friday and freezing rain warnings may be required for some locations. Snowfall amounts up to 5 cm are possible Friday afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-03T07:15:28-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A slow moving low pressure trough will give snow to Manitoba over the next couple of days. In the Red River Valley and Interlake, freezing drizzle will transition to snow this morning, with up to 10 cm today followed by another 5 to 10 cm tonight and a few more on Friday. In southeastern Manitoba near the Ontario border, precipitation will fall mainly as rain today, but freezing rain is likely for several hours tonight before transitioning to snow. Snow will continue all day Friday with totals of 10 to 20 cm. Snow will push northward from Norway House to Thompson, Brochet, and Tadoule Lake today, lingering through Friday and into Saturday as it gradually shifts towards Gillam, Shamattawa and Churchill. Snowfall warnings may also be required for these latter communities at some point in the next day or two. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are likely east of the Red River Valley and through central and northern Manitoba. Amounts will taper down as you go west from the Red River with little in the way of new snow forecast for Brandon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-03T07:20:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-02T15:21:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3478868165.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A slow moving low pressure trough will give snow to Manitoba over the next couple of days. In the Red River Valley and Interlake, freezing drizzle will transition to snow this morning, with up to 10 cm today followed by another 5 to 10 cm tonight and a few more on Friday. In southeastern Manitoba near the Ontario border, precipitation will fall mainly as rain today, but freezing rain is likely for several hours tonight before transitioning to snow. Snow will continue all day Friday with totals of 10 to 20 cm. Snow will push northward from Norway House to Thompson, Brochet, and Tadoule Lake today, lingering through Friday and into Saturday as it gradually shifts towards Island Lake, Gillam, Shamattawa and Churchill. Snowfall warnings may also be required for these latter communities at some point in the next day or two. Amounts will taper down as you go west from the Red River with little in the way of new snow forecast for Brandon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. Area: Molson Lake and Bear Lake, Cross Lake and Jenpeg, Wabowden, Hwy 6 between Little Limestone Lake and Ponton, Norway House, Brochet, Tadoule Lake, South Indian Lake and Amisk Prov. Park, Split Lake and York Landing, Thompson Thicket Portage and Pikwitonei, Nelson House
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A slow moving cold front will continue to bring significant snowfall to Manitoba over the next couple of days. In the Red River Valley and Interlake, heavy snow snow will persist tonight with additional snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm expected with the heavier amounts falling over eastern areas. The snow will gradually taper off from west to east on Friday with a few more centimetres possible over eastern areas. In southeastern Manitoba, the precipitation over most areas has now changed from rain to snow. However, near the Ontario border, there is still a risk of brief freezing rain this evening. The snowfall in this region is expected to be more intense with 15 to 25 cm occurring tonight and a further 5 to 10 cm falling on Friday before tapering off Friday evening. Heavy snow developing over the Thompson and Norway House areas will spread into the Lynn Lake, Brochet and Island Lake areas tonight before stalling and tracking northeastward into the Tadoule Lake and Gillam areas on Friday. Significant snowfall amounts are forecast in these regions with most areas receiving 15 to 30 cm by Saturday morning with even higher amounts possible along a northwest to southeast line through Thompson. The heavy snow will taper off over a number of areas Friday night into Saturday morning but persist over northeastern Manitoba until at least Sunday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-03T13:09:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-02T21:10:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1386805077.2020

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Additional snowfall: 2 to 4 cm. Locations: Nain and vicinity. Time span: continuing until this evening. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. Locations: Northeast-facing coastlines of Newfoundland and adjacent inland areas. Time span: midnight tonight until Friday morning. Remarks: Freezing drizzle is expected to be somewhat patchy tonight as temperatures hover around the freezing mark, but it will be most extensive over higher elevations where temperatures will be 1 to 2 degrees colder than at sea level. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing drizzle advisories are issued when drizzle falling in sub-zero temperatures is expected to freeze on contact, and over time create icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
